title: Red Wings are 2-for-2 in strong performances in net
text:
Carolina Hurricanes' Jordan Staal (11) has his shot blocked by Detroit Red Wings goalie Petr Mrazek (34) during the third period. (Photo: Karl B. DeBlaker / Associated Press) 
1 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Raleigh, North Carolina — Jimmy Howard was real good when called upon Friday.
And Saturday, with the Red Wings unable to find their legs early and seemingly killing penalties most of the game, Petr Mrazek was just as good while keeping the Red Wings in the game.
Mrazek’s heroics were rewarded late as the Red Wings rallied for a 4-3 victory Saturday in Carolina.
“Petr held us in for those two periods,” said coach Jeff Blashill, as Mrazek stopped 44 shots total.
Mrazek was sharp in the opening minutes as the Red Wings found themselves killing a two-man Carolina power play for 46 seconds, stopping Eric Staal on a great scoring attempt in close.
“It helps when the pucks hit you and they don’t go in,” Mrazek said of the quick flurry so early in the game. “It always feels good when you face so many shots and you give up three goals and you win.
“That was huge for our team (killing the early penalties).”
Blashill is likely to alternate, more or less, between Howard and Mrazek much of the first month or two with the schedule set up with so many back-to-backs.
Mrazek feels that will benefit both goalies.
“It’s 82 games in a season and playing about 12 games a month, it’s a lot of games, and a lot of back to backs too, so I feel like we should both stay sharp and be ready for games,” Mrazek said.
On a night the Red Wings needed strong goaltending, Mrazek certainly delivered.
“We gave up a lot of good chances over two periods, I don’t know if we gave up a ton of great chances, but good chances that Petr had to be strong on,” Blashill said. “There was a lot of action around our net that you have to be strong and he held his ground.
“Two nights in a row we’ve had real good goaltending and that’s what these two guys are and they’ll continue to get opportunities to prove it.”
Two in a row 
Blashill defeated his former boss Mike Babcock opening night, then on Saturday defeated Bill Peters, who was the other assistant on that Red Wings coaching staff in 2011 that Blashill was on.
Peters felt his team didn’t do a good enough job defensively over the final 20 minutes.
“We broke down in the D-zone,” Peters said. “We could have been a little firmer on the puck.”
Not capitalizing on early power plays and not being able to get a goal past Mrazek in the opening half of the game was a factor, too.
“We had some good looks there,” Peters said of the early power plays. “It would have nice to score on the 5-on-3 obviously. That was early in the game so it could have gave us a little momentum and some breathing room, but their goaltender played well.”
Ice chips 
The goal by Carolina’s Victor Rask in the second period ended a stretch of 95:12 the Red Wings hadn’t allowed a goal.
… Blashill used the same lineup Saturday as he did the night before, apart from Mrazek replacing Howard.
… In its season-opening loss Thursday, Carolins lost defenseman James Wisniewski (Canton) with a torn ACL which will force him to miss six months..
… Dylan Larkin and Carolina defenseman Noah Hanifin were teammates on the USA world junior team.
… The Hurricanes television network was identifying assistant coach Pat Ferschweiler as Blashill for much of the first period until finally getting it right.
